ISAs will be a part of the solution, 'debt' is better than 'equity' for many. The key change needed is for schools/training institutes to be on the hook for the education outcomes I launched an Income Share Agreement (ISA) company in 2019.

Our company survived, but our use of ISAs did not.

Overall, I think the ISA experiment has failed and is not the revolution we hoped would transform training and education.

Here's what I learned

"banks are apprehensive to grow the education loan portfolio in comparison to better risk-adjusted returns"
Higher education financing shouldn't be a social good... Also banks need to start adopting employability assessment frameworks

Most of the coding camps talk about the time wasted in college. I wish they had courses on psychology, philosophy / logic, and economics 'coz those are way more powerful than teaching someone how to center align a button

With the exception of a few, most of the coding camps are just committing the same mistakes we lament about the current education system. Or even narrowing the scope of things you learn via rote learning in a shorter timeframe.
Parallels between gardening and startups : Time taken for seedlings to grow is almost always more than predicted
